etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in Restoration of Sandwich to Christ Church. From the genitive of rede + man, perhaps after early Scandinavian; compare Old Icelandic ráðsmaðr, Old Danish radsmand (Danish (now rare) rådsmand, †raadsmand), Old Swedish rads man (Swedish (now archaic or historical) rådsman), all in senses ‘counsellor, adviser’, in Swedish also ‘member of a council’. Compare also Old Frisian rēdesmann counsellor, adviser, advocate, Middle Dutch raetsman (Dutch raadsman), German Ratsmann, both in sense ‘counsellor, adviser, member of a council’, Middle Low German rēdesman advocate
